head.title: Night-Vision Gear Provided To Help Track Coyotes

hedline.hl1: Night-Vision Gear Provided To Help Track Coyotes

abstract.p: Coyote attacks in Middletown prompt New Jersey Environmental Protection Department, working with US Agriculture Department wildlife experts, to equip teams with night-vision equipment to track and kill animals (S)

block.p: Coyote attacks in Middletown have prompted the State Department of Environmental Protection, working with wildlife experts at the United States Department of Agriculture, to equip teams with night-vision equipment to track and kill the animals.

Coyote attacks in Middletown have prompted the State Department of Environmental Protection, working with wildlife experts at the United States Department of Agriculture, to equip teams with night-vision equipment to track and kill the animals.
''Unfortunately there is no way to move the pack, so they're going to have to be sacrificed,'' said Lisa P. Jackson, the state environmental commissioner.

The state believes the coyotes in Middletown are a ''particularly bold'' family pack that has lost its fear of humans, Ms. Jackson said. ''I think we might be able to keep this a relatively isolated incident,'' she said.
State officials estimate that there are 3,000 coyotes in New Jersey.

In April, a coyote attacked a 20-month-old boy, and a 5-year-old boy was bitten by a coyote in May, said Eugene P. Hannafey, the deputy chief of police in Middletown. Both victims have recovered, he said.
Middletown requested assistance from the Department of Environmental Protection after the first attack because employees of the township are not trained to handle wildlife, he said.
Both attacks occurred near the Naval Weapons Station Earle, a sprawling base with sections in Colts Neck and Middletown that are connected by a 15-mile military road.

Mr. Hannafey said that the city set 30 traps near the base after the first attack but had not caught any coyotes. An officer shot and killed a coyote the same week as the second attack, but there was no way of determining if it had attacked either child, he said.
Pat Fisher, a spokesman for the Naval Weapons Station, said that no coyotes had been sighted on the base and that a Navy natural resources team did not find any evidence of coyotes.
